Message.Title: POTUS in 2016
Message.Msg: Franken Looks Like Heavy Favorite for Re-election Sen. Al Franken (D-MN) "looked to be a top GOP pickoff target next year after his agonizing seven-month recount and legal battle put him in the Senate in 2009 by a mere 312 votes," Politico reports. "Yet, in a turnabout few could've predicted, Franken has yet to draw a Republican opponent. The GOP looks likely to choose between relatively unknown state legislators, inexperienced businessmen or a conservative radio host with a history of controversial statements." A big win would position Franken as the "left of Hillary" alternative .

Message.Title: Another Obama TRIUMPH!!
Message.Msg: Health Insurance Rate Shock-California Obamacare Insurance Exchange Announces Premium Rates (Forbes) Covered California—the name given to the healthcare exchange created pursuant to the Affordable Care Act that will serve the largest population of insured citizens in the nation—released the premium rates submitted by participating health insurance companies for the three health insurance program categories (bronze, silver and gold) established by the Affordable Care Act, along with the catastrophic policy created for and available to those under the age of 30. Upon reviewing the data, I was indeed shocked by the proposed premium rates—but not in the way you might expect. The jolt that I was experiencing was not the result of the predicted out-of-control premium costs but the shock of rates far lower than what I expected—even at the lowest end of the age scale.

Topic.Title: PricewaterhouseCoopers: Obamacare will save businesses & employees money

Message.Msg: Er, the only active part of Obamacare currently in operation is the program for uninsurable people, which is no longer taking applicants due to price overruns. Since no other part of the bill has seen implementation it would be hard to find more than the one failure. Most of the collapses, like the last ditch insurance plan, will last at least two years after implementation, and with full implementation not scheduled until early 2014, that means the weight of those failures will fall on the NEXT President, even if he is perfectly aware of them, unless his party controls the house he won't be able to avoid them. You can keep almost any government program running two years on hope and promises, after that you had better be able to point to reasonable results or people may start asking questions . . . And given the attention this bill has gotten even before the relevant agency law has been crafted (in fact the end result of this bill will almost entirely be agency law since the legislatures dropped the ball on specifics) anything short of reasonable success given resources invested will invite condemnation. Frankly I hope it works, and that eventually the government fells comfortable dissolving the VA in favor of some kind of government blue cross/blue shield card, but until they do that I'm going to be convinced that the ACA is nothing but a shell game.

Topic.Title: POTUS in 2016

Message.Msg: I'll miss Hillary as Secretary of State, I haven't laughed so hard since the McCrystal scandal blew up thanks to Rolling Stone oh so many years ago. Of course the outcome of Benghazi wasn't that funny, but seeing the picture of the President of the United States UTTERLY humiliating the Emperor of Japan by bowing to him as a subordinate was just too amusing, along with the many other gaffes along the way. As President well . . . I could live with that as I don't think those around her will let her do much more damage than she did at the State Department. Of course she could go alittle nuts with the power thing, but that's fairly typical of almost all Presidents save Ford, Carter, Bush I, and . . . no one else I can think of from the last quarter of the century. Carter caught the power bug after he got out, but fortunately by then his reputation had mitigated his potential for damage, and given that he wasn't trusted, nor did he want to be trusted, with a great deal of national security information, he isn't the walking potential intelligence coup that more recent POTUS's may represent, for all that he seems in better physical health than all of them save President Obama. Must be something to peanuts that the department of Agriculture isn't telling us.

Topic.Title: This could explain why ETFC is up today

Message.Msg: On top of which its likely to put the 11's behind us by the end of the week with perhaps a few tests, and drive many of the remaining longer term shorts out. Unfortunately I think we'll also see some fund shorting if it break out into the mid $12's before the next earnings, and that might slow us down. Otherwise, yes, we're finally starting to see the value for which I bought into this company bringing returns, which is why instead of re-creating a higher bar for my long term equity hold I took my last short term position, cashed it in, and I bought a ton of LEAPS this month. By the time they're close to expiration our stock price should actually be close to a fair market value.

Message.Title: Will Oklahoma U.S. senators see value of public aid now?
Message.Msg: Published: Friday, May. 24, 2013 - 11:05 am Last Modified: Friday, May. 24, 2013 - 11:56 am Re "Shelters optional in tornado zone" (Page A1, May 22): The Oklahoma tornado was devastating for it citizens and hopefully they will receive the assistance needed to recover from this tragic event. However, I fully expect the two U.S. senators from Oklahoma, James Inhofe and Tom Coburn, who voted consistently against FEMA funding and voted down relief for Hurricane Sandy relief, to reject federal aid and rely solely on the Red Cross, private charities and direct relief donations to rebuild. Both senators are extreme fiscal hawks and believe in small government, rugged individualism and personal responsibility. This crisis will test their resolve and adherence to this ideology. However, in the end, hypocrisy on this would not surprise me. The voters should rise up and reject public funding as they rejected government regulations to build safer schools that might have saved the lives of the children who were killed as a result of the tornado.

Topic.Title: scandalous tea party conressman who feeds in the public trough

Message.Msg: Heritage is correct. As most government programs, farm subsidies by addressing one problem creates opportunity for fraud and abuse. But once those subsidies are available to every farmer, they should take it, or else they jeopardize their business in case things do go south and without those subsidies they wouldn't be able to compete with other farmers who took advantage of farm subsidies, i.e. unable to sell their product for competitive price. So first, your beloved government distributes money to all farmers, than it blames farmers for taking it? It's corruption on highest level. Put everyone in same conditions. Either eliminate the whole darn program and let chips fall where they may, or shut up with blaming farmer for accepting those funds. It's disingenuous.

Topic.Title: Another Obama TRIUMPH!!

Message.Msg: Obamacare’s Other Surprise (NYT) LISTENING to the debate about President Obama’s health care plan, some critics argue that Obamacare is going to need Obamacare — because it’s going to be a “train wreck.” Obama officials insist they’re wrong. We’ll just have to wait and see whether the Affordable Care Act, as the health care law is officially known, surprises us on the downside. But there is one area where the law already appears to be surprising on the upside. And that is the number of health care information start-ups it’s spurring. This is a big deal. The combination of Obamacare regulations, incentives in the recovery act for doctors and hospitals to shift to electronic records and the releasing of mountains of data held by the Department of Health and Human Services is creating a new marketplace and platform for innovation — a health care Silicon Valley — that has the potential to create better outcomes at lower costs by changing how health data are stored, shared and mined. It’s a new industry.

Topic.Title: Political Correct #$%$-London Beheading

Message.Msg: You don't carry in uniform on leave or in town, you carry in civvies using your state concealed carry permit (if the state requires one). Downside, if your weapons in the arms room you gotta have signed permission from the company commander to draw it. If he leaves for the weekend before you draw your weapon you can BET he won't come back in just to sign off, so you gotta make sure to draw it BEFORE the arms room closes on Friday, and insure you can turn it in to a secure location if you return to the barracks before the weekend is out. GENERALLY its a pain in the rear in main force units, though the SOCOM guys have it easier. Still, if you want to carry the weapon you have to go through the hassle.

Message.Title: Obama spreading the wealth around
Message.Msg: The Hamptons...Laughable! Summer Rentals Hit $1 Million in the Hamptons If you think your rent is high, consider summer rentals in the Hamptons. Brokers say there are now at least a half dozen homes and estates in the Hamptons that are renting for around $1 million-just for the summer. That works out to $9,803 per day, or $408 an hour. And the $1 million lease doesn't include utility bills or other charges, which can run in the tens of thousands. Brokers say the number of million-dollar rentals marks a new record. "It's unprecedented," said H. Dolly Lenz, a Manhattan broker who also works with buyers and renters in the Hamptons. "The demand is not just strong, it's unbelievable."

The report cited serious issues of accountability removing a few of the U.S. Attorneys, but there was no finding that the nine U.S. Attorneys were removed for illegal or improper reasons." "As the Wall Street Journal reported “the Justice Department informed Congress on Wednesday that a special investigator in the case found no evidence of wrongdoing….the investigator’s final word is that no Administration official gave ‘false statements’ to Congress or to the DOJ Inspector General, which carried out their own investigation.” The report also found no evidence that Gonzales made false or misleading statements to Congress, thus clearing him of accusations of perjury." Topic.Title: AG Eric Holder has no reason to resign

Message.Msg: AlterNet / By Liliana Segura COMMENT NOW! Alberto Gonzales: Will Lie for Food The New York Times reports that the former attorney general can't find a job. That should be the least of his problems. April 14, 2008 | Days after it is finally confirmed that the highest officials in American government signed off on torture in the days after 9/11, pending "a legal opinion on the legality of these tactics" in order to justify them, the New York Times reports that former Attorney General Alberto Gonzales, "like many others recently unemployed," is having trouble getting a job. "Mr. Gonzales, the former attorney general, who was forced to resign last year, has been unable to interest law firms in adding his name to their roster, Washington lawyers and his associates said in recent interviews." Can't really call it accountability. Karma? Not unless one of his job interviews has involved waterboarding. After all, for all the current controversy, it's not exactly news that the famous "torture memos" were authorized by Gonzales. But, about his job search: "What makes Mr. Gonzales's case extraordinary," the Times goes on, in typical dispassionate-to-the-point-of-obtuse tone, "is that former attorneys general, the government's chief lawyer, are typically highly sought." Hm, yes. Highly unusual. In fact, what made Alberto Gonzales extraordinary was his criminal conduct as the top law enforcement officer in the country. Half a year has passed since the attorney general resigned, skulking out of the Department of Justice to the dismay of no one but President Bush. But it's hardly a distant memory what a destructive figure he was at the DoJ. It was a year ago at this time that Gonzales was testifying before the Senate Judiciary Committee about

Message.Title: The Donald is at it again
Message.Msg: Trump has already spent 1 Million in research for a possible presidential run TRUMP'S POLITICAL HISTORY The real estate mogul has talked about a desire to add Commander in Chief to his resume for a number of years, starting in 2000 when he said he would run as a third party candidate. In 2004 and 2008, h talked about running as a Republican, and eventually endorsing the party's 2008 candidate, Senator John McCain. He did the same- but this time for Mitt Romney-in 2012,although he did hold out until April before endorsing the former Massachusetts governor. Much of his public speculation in 2012 stemmed from his dislike of President Obama- including his hiring of private investigators to search for Obama's 'real' birth certificate. Critics lampooned Trumps' most recent 'run' as a farce used simply to increase ratings on his reality show, The Celebrity Apprentice.
